title: venezuela passport leave economy maduro colombia border immigration
story: Created with Sketch.UN says 2.3 million people have left the country since 2015, but those without a passport are unable to escapeClick to followThe Independent USPeople wait in line outside Saime offices in Caracas  After a year struggling to make ends meet under Venezuela’s crushing hyperinflation, Jennyfer and her boyfriend decided to flee the country. Everything was ready, except a small but important detail: Jennyfer’s passport.It is now five months since Jennyfer Avero applied for her travel document. But, until today, the 23-year-old craftswoman from Caracas hasn’t anything about the state of her request.&nbspLast month, her boyfriend Javier left for&nbspEcuador, becoming part of one of the biggest exoduses in Latin American history. And in the meantime, Jennyfer continues to wait, hoping she will join him soon.“I have no alternative,” she says. “I wouldn’t like to leave without a passport.”Venezuela’s intensifying economic and political crisis has pushed hundreds of thousands to flee the country. They are in search of food, security, medicine and jobs.But not everyone&nbspthat makes the decision to leave has a valid passport. Venezuelans face multiple difficulties when trying to obtain this document. Some people can wait months, or even years, to get it. The process can be complicated, expensive and sometimes illegal.Day after day crowds queue up outside the headquarters of the passport agency, known as Saime, in Caracas.Saime has more than 200 offices nationwide, however many people come to the headquarters in Caracas hoping to get a passport. Here the possibilities are greater, users say.Everyone is here – women, children, couples and elderly people. Some arrived before dawn&nbspothers, those who came from afar, spent the night here. Much of them share the desire to leave the country for good.“This is the fourth time in three months I’ve come here,” says Jose Di Marco, while standing in line.Di Marco travelled 713km by bus from the town of Puerto Ordaz to Caracas. For the second consecutive day, the 20-year-old student has been sleeping at a nearby square to avoid losing his spot in the queue.He should be travelling to Ecuador at the end of the month. He has been awarded a full scholarship to study performing arts, but if he doesn’t arrive in time it will be taken away.Without answers about the status of his application, which he has been processing since 2016, he’s starting to feel desperate.“I’ve thought about leaving without a passport, I can’t waste more time,” he says.AFPGetty Images)The passport system began to fail two years ago. In theory, the process is easy. It’s done through a web page in which the citizen requests an appointment, attends the appointment and is given the passport within a couple of weeks. But often, users say, the website crashes and the appointment gets cancelled or people’s data just disappears from the system.“It’s as if I had never attended the appointment,” says Delia Cabral, 52, whose data disappeared from the website after she went to her meeting.The accountant has been waiting since May for her passport. Her daughter is waiting for her in Spain.It’s as if I had never attended the appointment&nbspExperts say that Caracas’s telecommunication infrastructure is one of the weakest in the region, so it is not surprising that high-traffic websites collapse.In July, a new head of Saime was named. He promised a complete renovation of the website, as well as a profound restructuring of the organisation. However, the system still seems to be failing.The passport agency has blamed shortages of materials, like paper and plastic, for the delays.Venezuela has been suffering from shortages of food, medicines and other basic goods for many years now. The lack of passports is just one of them.The legal price of a passport in Venezuela is 18 bolivars, or $0.30 (£0.23) at the black market exchange rate. However, tired of waiting, some Venezuelans choose to pay for the service of officials who can speed up the process for $1,000, at the very least. A prohibitively expensive amount for most Venezuelans,given the monthly minimum wage is $18.Maduro urges Venezuelan migrants to return home from ‘economic slavery’ in other countriesThis is an illegal practice for which several Saime officials have been arrested in recent months. The institution also blames those members of the “mafia”&nbspinside the passport agency for the delays.The economic and social crisis has become so unbearable that hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans consider escaping the country to be their only option – a feeling that has only increased over the past few months.President Nicolas Maduro denies the existence of a migration crisis and blames his critics for inflating the numbers.The government typically does not publish data, but the UN estimates that 2.3 million Venezuelans have fled the country since 2015, especially to neighbouring countries like Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Brazil. In August, the UN warned the migration exodus was reaching a “crisis moment”,&nbspakin to the situation in Mediterranean.&nbspLast month, Ecuador and Peru tightened their migration controls for Venezuelans, requiring them to show valid passports at the border. That decision left many Venezuelans who had been travelling without passports in limbo.The measure was later overturned. Over recent weeks, 11 Latin American countries agreed to allow Venezuelans to enter their countries even if their passports have expired.While this is a relief for those who haven’t been able to renew their travel documents, nothing changes for those who have never had a passport, like Jennyfer.“It makes no difference for me,” she says “I’m still stuck in here.”Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: china uighurs human rights muslims orphanages xinjiang province reeducation
story: Created with Sketch.‘It’s like my kids are in jail,’&nbspsays 29-year-old mother living in exileStaff and agenciesClick to followThe IndependentChina is putting Uighur children in 'orphanages' even if their parents are aliveChinese authorities are putting the children of Uighurs and other ethnic minority groups into dozens of state-run orphanages across the western Xinjiang region even if their parents are not dead, as some 1 million adults in their families are sent to internment camps.The orphanages are the most recent manifestation of Beijing’s efforts to systematically distance young Muslims in Xinjiang from their families and culture. Uighurs fear such efforts are erasing their ethnic identity, one child at a time.&nbspIn Istanbul,&nbspa dozen Uighur families spoke to reporters during the Muslim holy festival Eid al-Adha, which comes with large family reunions. Tables in every home were resplendent with traditional Xinjiang dishes like homemade noodles, freshly butchered lamb and crispy naan.&nbspBut the Uighurs who fled China to avoid detention described the&nbsppainful absence of the children they left behind – who they believe are now in the hands of the very government tearing their families apart.&nbspSome did not want their full names used for fear of retribution against relatives still in Xinjiang.Every morning, Meripet wakes up to her nightmare: the Chinese government has turned four of her children into orphans, even though she and their father are alive.&nbspMeripet and her husband left the kids with their grandmother at home in China when they went to nurse Meripet’s sick father in Turkey. But after Chinese authorities started locking up thousands of their fellow ethnic Uighurs for alleged subversive crimes such as travel abroad, that&nbspvisit became exile.&nbspThen&nbspher mother-in-law was also taken prisoner, and Meripet learned from a friend that her offspring, aged between three and eight,&nbsphad been placed in a de facto orphanage in the Xinjiang region&nbspunder the care of the state that broke up her family.&nbsp“It’s like my kids are in jail,” Meripet said, her voice cracking. “My four children are separated from me and living like orphans.”&nbspMeripet’s family is among tens of thousands swept up by President Xi Jinping‘s campaign to subdue a sometimes restive region, including the internment of more than 1 million Uighurs and other Muslim minorities that has alarmed a United Nations panel and the US&nbspgovernment. The UK Foreign Office also believes Beijing has “introduced intrusive security and surveillance measures and cultural restrictions” aimed at the Uighur people, including “re-education camps”.Now there is evidence that the government is placing the children of detainees and exiles into dozens of orphanages across Xinjiang.&nbspThe institutions are the latest example of how China is systematically distancing young Muslims in Xinjiang from their families and culture,&nbspinterviews with more than a dozen people and a review of procurement documents suggest. The government has been building thousands of so-called “bilingual” schools, where minority children are taught in Mandarin and penalised for speaking in their native tongues. Some of these are boarding schools, which Uighurs say can be mandatory for children and, in one Kazakh family’s case, start from the age of five.&nbspBut Uighurs fear that these measures are essentially wiping out their ethnic identity, one child at a time. Experts say what China is doing echoes how white colonialists in the US, Canada and Australia treated indigenous children – policies that have left generations traumatised.&nbsp“This is an ethnic group whose knowledge base is being erased,” said Darren Byler, a researcher of Uighur culture at University of Washington. “What we’re looking at is something like a settler colonial situation where an entire generation is lost.”&nbspFor Meripet, the loss is agony it is the absence of her children and the knowledge they are in state custody. A year and a half after leaving home, the 29-year-old mother looked at a photo of a brightly painted building surrounded by barbed wire where her children are believed to be held. She fell silent. And then she wept.&nbsp“When I finally see them again, will they even recognise me?” she asked. “Will I recognise them?”&nbspWhen Mr Xi came to power in 2012, an early challenge to his rule was a surge in violent attacks that killed several hundred people and which Beijing pinned on Uighur separatists. Since then, he&nbsphas overseen the most extensive effort in recent years to quell Xinjiang, appointing in 2016 the former Tibet party boss Chen Quanguo to lead the troubled region bordering Afghanistan.&nbspChen rolled out unprecedented security measures such as the internment camps that hold Muslims without trial and force them to renounce their faith and swear loyalty to the ruling Communist Party. China has described religious extremism as an illness that needs to be cured through what it calls “transformation through education”. Former detainees say one can be thrown into a camp for praying regularly, reading the Quran, going abroad or even speaking to someone overseas.&nbspThe camps are among the most troubling aspects of Mr Xi’s campaign to assert the party’s dominance over all aspects of Chinese life, which has drawn comparisons with Mao Zedong. Authorities heeding Mr Xi’s call to “Sinicise” religion across the country have shut underground churches, burnt&nbspBibles, replaced pictures of Jesus with ones of the president, and toppled crescents from mosques. The party also has beefed up its ability to track the movements of its 1.4 billion people, with Xinjiang serving as an important testing ground.&nbspIn Xinjiang, detention has left countless children without their parents. Most of these families in China cannot be reached by journalists. However, reporters interviewed 14 Uighur families living in Turkey and one Kazakh man in Almaty with a total of 56 children who remain in China.&nbspThe families say that among these children, 14 are known to be in state-run orphanages and boarding schools. The whereabouts of the rest are unknown because most of their adult relatives in Xinjiang have been detained.&nbspSome interviewees, like Meripet, requested that they be identified only by their first names because they feared official retaliation against their relatives. Others insisted their full names be used despite the risks, saying they were desperate for their stories to be heard. They pleaded with reporters to track down their families in Xinjiang, and one interviewee pressed a piece of paper into a reporter’s hand with a Chinese address scribbled on it.&nbspThe regional government appears to be moving quickly to build centres to house the children of these exiles and of detainees. A review of procurement notices in Xinjiang has found that since the start of last year, the government has budgeted more than $30m&nbsp(200 million Chinese yuan, £22.7m) to build or expand at least 45 orphanages, known variously as “welfare centres” and “protection centres”, with enough beds to house about 5,000 children.&nbspIn July and August alone, the government invited bids for the construction of at least nine centres for the “protection of disadvantaged children” in the Xinjiang city of Hotan and several counties in Kashgar, Aksu and Kizilsu prefectures, inhabited primarily by ethnic minority groups. Most orphanages have a minimum of 100 beds mandated by the government, and some are much larger. One notice called for an orphanage in Moyu county with four four-story dormitories, coming to 22,776 sq&nbspmetres in size – bigger than three&nbspfootball pitches.&nbspThese numbers do not include kindergartens and other schools where some children of Uighur detainees are being housed. It’s impossible to tell how many children of detainees end up at these schools because they also serve other children.&nbspShi Yuqing, a Kashgar civil affairs official, said that “authorities provide aid and support to everyone in need, whether they’re the children of convicted criminals or people killed in traffic accidents”. But such services may not be welcome. A government report from Bayingolin Mongol Autonomous Prefecture in June last year acknowledged that relatives were resistant to “handing over” their extended families’ kids to the orphanages because they “lack trust or confidence” in the centres.&nbspA friend told Meripet last November her four children were living in the Hotan City Kindness Kindergarten in southern Xinjiang. The friend said Meripet’s sister-in-law had visited her children and was permitted to take them home for one night only.&nbspThe school looks like a house-sized castle, with a bright marigold facade, orange turrets and blue rooftops. Its entrance is blocked by an iron gate and a walled enclosure lined with barbed wire. “We Are Happy and Grateful to the Motherland”, say the red characters emblazoned on one fence.&nbspThe principal, who gave only her last name, Ai, told reporters that the institution was “just a normal kindergarten”. But the authorities’ anxiety was clear: armed police officers surrounded the reporters’ car minutes after their arrival at the school and ordered them to delete any photos.&nbspGu Li, a propaganda official for Hotan who also immediately appeared on the scene, added: “There are really young kids here – some of them may even be orphans whose parents have died.”&nbspHotan City Kindness Kindergarten (AP)A report published this February in the Xinjiang Daily, a party newspaper, called Hotan City Kindness Kindergarten a “free, full-time” kindergarten for children aged six and younger that provides accommodations and clothing to those whose “parents cannot care for them for a variety of reasons”.&nbsp“Soon after many of the kids arrived at the school, they grew taller and got fatter, and quickly started using Mandarin to communicate,” the article said. Another state media report in January said $1.24m had been invested in the kindergarten.&nbspSatellite imagery shows that the kindergarten had been constructed less than three years ago, just as an initiative was launched to strengthen “bilingual” education in Xinjiang. More than 4,300 bilingual kindergartens were built or renovated last year, according to the government. A report on the project in a state-run regional newspaper said such kindergartens taught children “civilised living habits”.&nbsp“The children started educating their parents: your hands are too dirty, your clothes are too dirty, you haven’t brushed your teeth,” the report quoted Achilem Abduwayit, a deputy chief of the Hotan city education bureau, as saying.&nbspLife in an orphanage could have a lasting psychological and cultural impact on children, said James Leibold, an expert on Chinese ethnic policy at La Trobe University in Melbourne, Australia.&nbsp“You grow up as a ward of the state,” he said. “They’re told to be patriotic citizens, told that the identity and religion of their parents was abnormal, if not radical, and thus needs to be eradicated.”&nbspMeripet has at least an inkling of where her children are. Her brother, a 37-year-old doctor named Aziz, has not heard any news of his three youngest children since his wife was taken to a re-education centre in June 2017.&nbspAziz fled to Turkey more than a year ago after he received a call from his local police station ordering him to report to authorities immediately. More than half his neighbours had already been taken away to re-education centres or prison, he said.&nbspNow the young doctor is often shaken awake by a nightmare in which his kids are huddling at the bottom of a cliff, their faces smudged with dirt, calling to him to hoist them up. Aziz walks for what feels like hours but cannot reach them. He awakens with their cries ringing in his ears.&nbsp“If I could, I would choose not to have been born as a Uighur, to not have been born in Xinjiang,” Aziz said. “We are the most unfortunate ethnic group in the world.”&nbspWorld news in picturesA boat has capsized killing at 136 people in Lake Victoria, Tanzania. A former teacher at a “bilingual” kindergarten outside Kashgar said all lessons were given in Mandarin and the entirely Uighur student body was banned from speaking Uighur at school. A colleague who used Uighur to explain concepts to students was fired, according to the teacher, who lives in Turkey but asked for anonymity because she fears retribution against family in China.&nbspLike all schools in China, this one immersed children in patriotic education. Kindergarten textbooks were filled with songs like “Without the Communist Party, There Would Be No New China”, the teacher said.&nbspDilnur, a 35-year-old business student in exile in Istanbul, said officials regularly visited her children’s kindergarten in Kashgar and asked the students if their parents read religious verses at home or participated in other faith-based activities. The questions effectively forced children to spy on their own families. A man was taken away by police after his grandson said in class that he had made a pilgrimage to Mecca, she said.&nbspHer seven-year-old daughter once complained that her throat was sore from chanting party slogans. “Mama, what does it mean to love the motherland?” she asked.&nbspSome bilingual schools are boarding schools, which are not uncommon in China. Xinjiang has long provided voluntary boarding school programmes that are seen as coveted opportunities for the best minority students. But several Uighurs asserted that in many cases boarding school was now mandatory for minority children, even though Han Chinese children could choose to continue living at home.&nbspThe Xinjiang government did not respond to repeated requests for comment. The government has said the tuition-free boarding schools relieve parents of education and living expenses and help raise Mandarin standards, which will make their children more employable.&nbspBut Uighurs say they do not want their culture erased.&nbspGulzar Seley, who was detained in China along with her newborn son, is placed on a table in the home of her husband Halmurat Idris in Istanbul (AP)“If the kids are forced to speak Mandarin and live like Han Chinese every day, I’m afraid they won’t be like us anymore,” said Meriyem Yusup, whose extended family has four children sent to state-run orphanages in Xinjiang.&nbspAdil Dalelkhan, an ethnic Kazakh sock merchant in exile in Almaty, said that even though his then five-year-old son could live with relatives, he was forced to stay at his preschool Monday&nbspthrough Friday instead. The father called the policy a “terrifying” step towards extinguishing Kazakh culture.&nbspA Uighur businessman in Istanbul, also named Adil, told a similar story. Adil’s son was nine&nbspyears old when the school system automatically transferred him to a boarding school. All children of a certain age in their Uighur district were obliged to attend boarding school, Adil said. His son was only permitted to come home on weekends and holidays.&nbsp“There were iron bars like we saw in a zoo in Kashgar,” Adil recalled.&nbspDilnur said her neighbours too were only allowed to visit their kids at boarding school on Wednesday nights, and even then they had to hand them sweets through a fence.&nbsp“The educational goals are secondary to the political goals,” said Timothy Grose, a professor at Indiana’s Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology who has done research on Xinjiang boarding schools. “They aim to dissolve loyalties to ethnic identity ... toward a national identity.”&nbspA government notice posted in February in Kashgar states that children in the fourth grade and above with parents in detention must be sent to boarding school immediately – even if one parent is still at home. Students must be instilled with socialist values, the notice said, and be taught to “be grateful for education and love and repay the motherland”, and avoid the “75 types of behaviour that show religious extremism”. Such behaviour ranges from calling for “holy war” to growing beards and quitting smoking and drinking for religious reasons, the government says.&nbspChina insists it guarantees&nbspfreedom of religion, but Uighurs view the Chinese education system as a threat to it. In schools, children are taught to respect teachers more than their parents and may begin to criticise their parents’ Islamic faith, according to Byler.&nbsp“The students, children, might question them and say, you know, this is backward, this is extremist,” he said.&nbspThe Kashgar notice also said schools being modified to house students should place no more than 24 beds in one room – an indication of the programme’s size. In 2015, a sprawling new boarding school complex was completed on the outskirts of Kashgar, with the capacity to house 23,400 students and teachers, according to the state-run China Daily.&nbspAbdurehim Imin, a writer from Kashgar, said a friend told him his 14-year-old daughter had been sent to a bilingual school in 2015 after his wife was arrested, ostensibly for receiving a gift of olive oil he sent her. When reporters visited what appeared to be his daughter’s school, Peyzawat County No 4 High School, a local plainclothes officer who identified herself as Gu Li said it was a bilingual boarding school. She said that while Uighur students had to study Mandarin, there were also Han Chinese students studying Uighur.&nbspYet the exterior of the school bore bright red lettering that said: “Please speak Mandarin upon entering the schoolyard”. Barbed wire around the campus extended for miles, with rows of tall apartment buildings marked as dormitories.&nbspA historian at the University of Sydney, David Brophy, said the move towards boarding schools brought to mind Aboriginal children in Australia who were forcibly separated from their families in the 1900s and placed into state-run institutions that discouraged indigenous identity.&nbsp“Should China’s policies continue in this direction, we may be talking about a Chinese version of the Stolen Generation,” he said.Since coming to Istanbul by himself in 2014, 42-year-old Imin, the writer, has led a solitary existence in a dimly lit apartment with bare walls and stacks of writings. For the first year, he avoided looking at photos of his children.&nbsp“We are dying every day,” Imin said. “We cannot see our kids, we cannot see our parents. This is an eternal torture.”&nbspIn December, he was sent a photo of his daughter wearing a traditional Chinese “qipao”. He deleted the picture because he could not bear to look at it, he said, and could not sleep for nearly a month.&nbspImin also has four other children in Xinjiang. Last summer, a friend who had visited his home in Kashgar told Imin that two of them had been killed in a traffic accident while his wife was in prison. He does not know where the other two are.&nbspFeeling helpless, he wrote verse after verse in mourning:&nbsp“I will go... to tear down your dark, endless night ...&nbspI will go, to embrace again my hometown ...&nbspI will go, bearing my sorrow to your tomb.”&nbspElsewhere in Istanbul, Meripet’s house was quiet during Eid al-Adha, a Muslim holy festival heralded by large family reunions. In a room at the end of the hall, there rose the distant laughter of relatives’ children.&nbspShe flipped through the photographs she keeps in her purse: Abdurahman, the oldest Adile, her only daughter and her two younger sons, Muhemmed and Abdulla. Meripet has a fifth child, a son named Abduweli who was born in Turkey. She calls him “my only light”.&nbsp“Sometimes I wonder if I will go crazy from this pain,” she says. “I have only been able to keep living because I know there is hope – I know one day I will see my children again.”Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

story: Created with Sketch.Click to followThe IndependentSaudi King Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud receives Pakistani prime minister Imran Khan in JeddahIslamabad has invited Saudi Arabia to become the third partner in the Beijing-funded Belt and Road corridor of major infrastructure projects inside Pakistan.The announcement comes on the back of a two-day trip to Saudi Arabia by new prime minister Imran Khan, who had been expected to push for financial assistance from Islamabad's ally to help Pakistan deal with a brewing currency crisis.Information minister Fawad Chaudhry did not reveal if Saudi Arabia would be loaning money to Pakistan to help top up its dwindling foreign currency reserves, but said he expected Saudi Arabia to invest in Pakistan in a major way.Saudi Arabia is the first country whom we have invited as third country partner in CPEC, Chaudhry said, referring to the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), the Pakistan leg of China's vast Belt and Road infrastructure initiative.Beijing has pledged $60bn&nbspto build power stations, major highways, new and upgraded railways and higher capacity ports, to help turn Pakistan into a major overland route linking western China to the world.Mr Chaudhry said a Saudi delegation will be coming to Pakistan in the first week of October, including the Saudi minister for finance and energy, and that should lay down a foundation for a very big partnership.God willing, very big investments will be coming to Pakistan from Saudi Arabia this way, he added.Mr Khan's term began with new doubt over the CPEC projects, when his commerce minister was quoted as saying Pakistan would suspend them for a year and review them. title: nature animals goose gosling ornithologist Michael Quetting
story: I used to fight and rage against the complications of my life, says Quetting, who was newly-orced and living away from his children at the time.But my seven goslings helped me find myself again. They showed me what really matters: loving others and loving life itself.The story of his journey to handrear the greylag geese in order to study them in flight is as heartwarming as it is surprising - particularly to Quetting himself.I didn't expect to become so attached to them, he says. I didn't expect to learn anything from them. I thought I would be teaching them, not the other way around.                We face mass extinctions in our back yard says TV Chris Packham                Gannets display shows the magic of nature, writes JOHN INGHAM Quetting spent a year caring for the goslings as they hatched, helping them learn to swim, and teaching them to fly alongside his Ultralight aircraft as part of an ambitious research programme undertaken by the Max Planck Institute in Germany to analyse animal movement on Earth.The goslings had to undergo imprinting, by which they would identify their human  as their parent and follow his lead.Baby geese aren't picky about choosing their parents, says Quetting.They latch on to whatever they first see after hatching: a human, a doll or even a football.Quetting and his brood take a rest but the adventurous Nemo is eager for another dip (Image: PR)But the work starts before the chicks have even hatched so it was important for him to spend as much time with the large white eggs as possible.The chicks have to be encouraged to hatch so the incubator they used was designed to mimic the brooding process - even down to Quetting taking the eggs out to cool every day for half an hour, before misting them with cold water to replicate conditions in the wild when the mother would leave the nest briefly to take a dip, and return with a wet bottom.He soon developed a strong bond with the unhatched chicks. I read them stories while they were still in the egg, he says.This was part of a scientific experiment, to ensure the chicks recognised me from the moment they were born and adopted me as their mother.The goal was for the geese, when fully grown, to wear small data loggers on their backs, which would transmit to ICARUS - International Cooperation for Animal Research Using Space. The ICARUS antennae were placed on the outside of the International Space Station last month by two Russian cosmonauts.The geese take flight with &lsquoPapa&rsquo in his Ultralight (Image: PR)Using tiny transmitters, ICARUS will analyse wildlife movement and track bird migration and habitat shifts in response to climate. The data will also provide real-time weather updates so, for example, a sailor in the Atlantic can change course if a storm is coming, explains Quetting.As the day of hatching approached, he grew as nervous as any prospective parent. At my daughter's insistence, he says, I named the firstborn gosling Gloria - mistaking him for a girl goose.As with a newborn baby, the first physical contact is critical, so Michael gently cuddled Gloria and whispered his best goose noises: Gagagaga! Weeweeweeweewee!When the goslings were all hatched, he moved into a trailer in the grounds of the Max Planck Institute, dubbed Duckingham Palace, with his brood: Gloria - by now renamed Glorio - Paul, Freddy, Nemo, Maddin. Nils and Calimero.Quetting initially believed he had three girls and four boys until DNA tests revealed an all-boy lineup.No sooner had he safely hatched all the chicks than it was time to get on with a few crucial life lessons, starting with swimming.                SNOW IN AFRICA: Giraffes, elephants and antelopes covered in snow                 Playful dolphin&rsquos baby has whale of a timeI was up at 5.15am as usual - the goslings gave me no choice - and put out a paddling pool, he recalls.Nemo was first to jump in but soon all the chicks were frolicking happily, splashing and playing submarines.Next came running and playing follow-my-leader, a game the goslings took to with ease.They raced after me like seven little golden tennis balls, writes Quetting in his book - which came about after media coverage of his daily blog brought this heartwarming tale to the attention of publishers Random House.It warmed my heart to see them running with their stubby wings outstretched, eager to be reunited with their Papa Goose.While the goslings were losing their baby down and learning new skills every day, Quetting, too, was undergoing a change.Michael Quetting accompany them in his light aircraft (Image: PR)Thanks to the geese, I was finding it easier to accept that, following my orce, I wasn't able to see my own children all the time, he says, a reference to his daughter Amelia, 13, and son Ronin, nine.The geese taught me to live in the moment, not the past or the future. I also turned my back on the internet, I stopped checking my phone all the time, as we humans do, and I didn't miss it. I felt at one with the geese and I felt happy and calm.There was a day of reckoning when Quetting decided to find out if his hours of encouraging them to fly would enable him to accompany them in his light aircraft.As his Ultralight soared into the sky, he honked his horn - the signal for the geese to take off - and they took flight, giving him the kind of bird's eye view that any twitcher would die for.I was surrounded by beating wings and rhythmically moving heads, says Quetting. I saw close up their goose aerobatics, how they will turn on to their backs in mid-air and e towards the ground before righting themselves. It seems they do it just because they can.His favourite manoeuvre was the landing: almost vertically, no need for a runway, coming down on their feet as gracefully as helicopters.The eggs&rsquo customised incubator (Image: PR)Unlike dogs and cats, geese do not make long-term pets and soon Quetting's flock began to break up. Freddy, always the most rebellious, was the first to go. He became disobedient and refused to fly with the rest, he says.But he returned and is now seen regularly - with Maddin - at a local boating lake, pestering visitors for scraps of bread.Tragically, Nemo died of a neck injury in the aviary, while Paul flew away one day and was never seen broth-again. Glorio, eldest of the brothers, answered the call of the wild and was last seen in the midst of a group of undomesticated greylags.Calimero and Nils were taken in by a wildlife park and Quetting visits them regularly.I miss the geese every day, he says. But their legacy stays with me. If ever I feel stressed, I recall those days with the goslings and it instantly calms me down. That is the lasting power of the geese which will stay with me for ever.During more than 60 flights together, Quetting gathered enough data for several PhD theses and proved that data loggers can be carried by geese in flight without any hindrance, opening the way for this method to be used by meteorologists all round the world.To order Papa Goose: One Year, Seven Goslings, And The Flight Of My Life by Michael Quetting (Greystone, &pound16.99) call the Express Bookshop on 01872 562310 with your card details. Alternatively send a cheque made payable to Express Bookshop to Papa Goose Offer, PO Box 200, Falmouth TR11 4WJ. Or order online at express bookshop. UK Delivery is free.

story: The Autumn Equinox will peak here in the UK around 2.54am BST when most enthusiastic skywatchers will still be snugly asleep in bed.But the astronomers at robotic telescope service Slooh will focus their instruments on the Sun tomorrow for you to watch the equinox from the comfort of your home.The Autumn Equinox live stream will kick off at 1am UK time, or 8pm EDT for viewers in the USA.Slooh teased: &ldquoDuring our live broadcast on the September equinox, we&rsquoll feature live views of the Sun from our partner telescopes all over the world and we&rsquoll reflect upon the physical and cultural meaning of equinox to world cultures throughout history.                Autumn Equinox 2018: What time is the September Equinox TOMORROW?                Autumn Equinox 2018: How is the September Equinox celebrated?You can watch the equinox broadcast live on Slooh&rsquos website here, but you will need to sign up for a Slooh account.Slooh memberships are either free or&nbspsubscription based&nbsp&ndash paid memberships will give you a chance to control one of Slooh&rsquos remote telescopes.Once you sign up, you will have a chance to watch Slooh&rsquos resident astronomers discuss the Autumn Equinox at length.Tomorrow&rsquos equinox live stream will feature appearances from veteran Slooh astronomer Paul Cox, space expert Dr Paige Godfrey and Slooh storyteller Helen Avery.Autumn Equinox live stream: You can watch the September Equinox on Slooh (Image: )Ms Avery will tune in to the equinox stream from the Lovelight Yoga festival in Maryland, USA.She said yesterday: &ldquoSo I&rsquove just arrived at the Lovelight Festival where 1,200 being are coming this weekend in Maryland to celebrate the equinox.&ldquoI look forward to seeing you on Slooh, live from this festival tomorrow as we celebrate the equinox.Slooh audiences are typically given an opportunity to submit questions to the Slooh team via Twitter which&nbspare&nbspthen answered live on air.                Autumn Equinox 2018: What is the Autumn Equinox?Similarly, in June and December the summer and winter solstice kick-start the astronomical seasons of summer and winter.Because the Earth is slightly titled towards the Sun at a&nbsp23.4 degree&nbspangle, the Sun always moves to the north or to the south of the equator.But twice a year, during the equinoxes, the Sun appears to pass directly over the imaginary line cutting the globe in half.Autumn Equinox 2018: The equinox falls on two dates every single year (Image: )Autumn Equinox 2018: In the Northern Hemisphere, the equinox is the start of astronomical autumn (Image: )The equinox results in&nbspdaytime&nbspand nighttime lasting roughly the same amount of time and this is reflected in the name equinox, which originates from the&nbsplatin&nbspwords for equal and night.Slooh said: &ldquoA celestial equinox is a point of balance in the cycles of the seasons.&ldquoMany world cultures regarded the equinox as a pivot point, a time when the world moves from light to darkness and back again.&ldquoTo&nbspsome, an equinox signified the struggle between the forces of darkness and decay and light and rebirth, and many spiritual leaders, both real and legendary, faced their greatest confrontation with darkness to attain the light at a time near the equinox.

title: Hurricane tracker tropical storm Kirk hurricane florence reform national hurricane center
story: Remnants of former Hurricane Florence could re-form in the Atlantic and hit the US East Coast once again, just over a week after the hurricane caused death and devastation in the Carolinas.Weather forecasters have said it is highly unlikely the storm will be as powerful as Florence but it was possible the tropical storm could impact next week.The National Hurricane Center (NHC) gives the system a 20 percent chance of organising in five days.The likelihood is Kirk will bring a further deluge of rain to a region which has already had some three feet of rain dumped on it.                Hurricane Florence RETURNS? Devastating storm could REFORM Victoria Oliva, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service&rsquos Wilmington office said even though there is a chance the former Florence re-forms, &ldquoit is not likely to find the extremely favourable conditions that fuelled Florence.She said: &ldquoIt is moving very slow, and it is not in a good environment. Right now, it is just a small system of storms.&ldquoBut there is a lot of dry air and strong upper level winds that would create shear, which tropical storms don&rsquot like.Steve Stewart, a meteorologist at ABC 11 in Raleigh said the latest models on the disturbance &ldquokeep this relatively weak and just some showers possible along the coast before a front swings it back out to sea.Hurricane tracker: Hurricane Florence could reform as another storm in the Atlantic (Image: NHC )Kirk has only been given a 20 percent chance of re-forming into a tropical depression or storm within the next five days.The NHC has warned Kirk may find conditions more conducive to slow strengthening next week.In an update on Friday morning the agency said: &ldquoAlthough a combination of dry air and strong upper-level winds is expected to inhibit any significant development over the next few days, the environment could become conducive for slow development when the system moves over the southwest Atlantic Ocean during the middle part of next week.Kirk is likely to impact the East Coast and could deliver more rain to the Carolinas.                Hurricane tracker LIVE map: Latest satellite images of storms                UK Weather: Hurricane Florence could bring &lsquoDANGER TO LIFE' windsHurricane tracker: Hurricane Florence has caused widespread devastation in North Carolina (Image: Getty )Ms Oliva added: &ldquoIt could bring some rainfall, but that might be seven or more days out.&ldquoRight now, it is all very, very unsure.The Carolinas are still reeling from the effects of Hurricane Florence, as some areas received 30 to 40 inches of rain over days and swollen rivers rise near or beyond their flood stages.Governor Roy Cooper said in a Twitter post: &ldquoSome locations won&rsquot see rivers crest until this weekend and flooding won&rsquot subside until next week.Hurricane tracker: Flooded homes are seen in this aerial photograph taken above North Carolina (Image: Getty )Some 4,700 people across North Carolina have been rescued by boat or helicopter since Florence made landfall.The coastal city of Wilmington, North Carolina, was still mostly cut off by floodwaters on Friday.In North Carolina, 31 death have been attributed to the storm, eight in South Carolina and one in Virginia.More than three dozen flood gauges in North and South Carolina showed flooding, according to the National Weather Service.

story: The head of Russia's space agency said it could pull out of the Deep Space Gateway project (Image:  IMAGESMikhail MetzelTASS)Moscow agreed last year to work with US on the NASA-led Deep Space Gateway, a proposed facility in lunar orbit which would serve as a staging post for future missions.But the head of Russian space agency Roscosmos, Dmitry Rogozin, cast doubt on the plans today and warned Russia could abandon the joint project because it does not want a &ldquosecond fiddle role.He said Russia may instead put forward its own proposals, Moscow-based news agency RIA quoted the agency boss as saying.He said: The Russian Federation cannot afford to play the second fiddle role in it.                Russia to STOP sending US astronauts to international space stationHis comments come just weeks after Russia confirmed it will stop flying US astronauts to the International Space Station in April next year once a contract promoting bilateral partnership of the project comes to an end.But just hours after Mr Rogozin warned Russia could quit the Deep Space Gateway project, Roscosmos insisted Russia had no immediate plans to leave.A spokesman for the space agency was quoted by the TASS news agency as saying: Russia has not refused to take part in the project of the lunar orbit station with the USA.NASA and Roscosmos announced in September last year that they would work together on the Deep Space Gateway concept with the aim of sending astronauts into lunar orbit by the 2020s.Dmitry Rogozin said Russia would not play a 'second fiddle' role in the NASA-led lunar space station (Image:  IMAGES)Deep Space Gateway could be used for lunar exploration or as a pit-stop for Mars missions (Image:  IMAGES)                Russia news: Putin to send robots to space by NEXT YEAR                US Space Force: USA unveil new armed force to conquer spaceThe initial outpost could then be expanded to provide a resupply point for crewed missions to Mars or further exploration of the moon.Construction on the project is due to begin in 2022 with the first modules of the Deep Space Gateway expected to be completed two years later.The craft itself would be powered by Nasa&rsquos newly created Solar Electric Propulsion &ndash technology which draws power from the sun to drive the spacecraft.The joint announcement was a rare moment of bilateral cooperation between Russia and the United States during a period of rising tensions between the two nuclear-armed nations.Russian rockets currently ferry US astronauts to the ISS, but this cooperation is set to end (Image:  IMAGES)Relations between Moscow and Washington have deteriorated in recent years and took a further hit following Russian attempts to influence in the 2016 US presidential election.President Donald Trump has attempted to improve cooperation with Moscow by engaging with Vladimir Putin.The US leader has insisted&nbspthat working with rather than against Russia would be in America&rsquos best interests.But despite initial hopes of a thawing in relations, Mr Trump&rsquos administration has reimposed sanctions against Russia in response to the Salisbury chemical attack.

story: But the Prime Minister faces substantial opposition — not least from within the Conservative Party. Heres what you need to know.After a marathon session of talks at Chequers on July 6, Theresa May managed to secure a Brexit plan which will be assessed by the EU.Her Brexit plan will see the UK remain closely tied to Brussels.It also includes the creation of a new UK-EU free trade area for goods with a common rulebook.This rulebook could limit the UKs ability to strike trade deals with countries such as the US — for whom securing market access for American farmers would be a big prize.Mrs May hopes to get an agreement hammered out at a series of summits with EU leaders this autumn, and bring it back to Parliament for approval.But her plans were dealt a blow at crunch talks in Salzburg with other EU leaders in September.The PM was ambushed by EU bullies who dismissed her Chequers plan out of hand.Maltese and Czech leaders told Britain to hold a second referendum, employing the same tactic that the EU has used in Ireland and Denmark before.Once a deal has been agreed —  ever — MPs will be asked to approve it.In a Panorama interview in September 2018 she said MPs had a simple choice between her Chequers plan or no deal.She told the BBC current affairs programme: I think that the alternative to that [the Chequers plan] will be not having a deal.Opposition to the plan in the Conservative Party centres around the European Research Group of Hard Brexit supporting MPs led by Jacob Rees-Mogg.His voice had been among the loudest voicing their objection to the plan and he urged MPs “chuck Chequers”.Up to 80 Tory MPs are prepared to vote against Theresa Mays Chequers plan, Steve Baker, a former Brexit minister and ERG backer has warned.A group of about 50 Tory MPs have met to discuss how and when they could force her out of her job, the BBC reported.Also voicing his opposition to the Chequers deal has been Boris Johnson.He said Theresas Mays had wrapped a suicide vest around the British constitution and handed the detonator to Brussels.The former Foreign Secretary later claimed Mrs Mays disastrous plans for the Irish border would leave Britain at a loss.Boris Johnson said the European Unions fallback position for the Irish border would mean Northern Ireland was annexed by Brussels.Along with former Brexit secretary David Davis, Mr Johnson resigned in protest following the Chequers meeting.Several other MPs also quit their ministerial posts over the issue, including Steve Baker, Maria Caulfield, Ben Bradley and Robert Courts.The party will vote down any Brexit deal brought back from Brussels by Theresa May, according to shadow Foreign Secretary Emily Thornberry.The Corbyn ally said the party will oppose it to try to force an election by Christmas.Speaking to the FT she said a deal which meets her party’s tests was “not going to happen”, and therefore the Prime Minister would be forced to quit.Without the support of the opposition party, it would need just a handful of Tory rebels to vote against her to see it defeated.Theresa Mays initial plans brought her on side with those Conservatives who favour a soft Brexit.The Prime Minister has also been seeking grassroots Tory support for the plan.Among those voicing support for the Prime Minister has been Environment Secretary Michael Gove, who was a prominent member of the Leave campaign.He said he was confident that the Prime Minister will go into the Conservative Party conference and beyond, securing a good Brexit deal for Britain and continuing to ensure the country enjoys good economic growth and we take advantage of Brexit.A plan may have been cooked up but it still needs to get past the EU — and the continent’s leaders are showing no sign of compromise.Angela Merkel is already rubbishing our proposal.The Napoleonic Emmanuel Macron thinks he’s a political messiah, and he’d rather see us punished than give up on his federalist promised land.And Michel Barnier’s dangled “concessions” amount to a demand for total UK capitulation.With that level of zeal and stubbornness, it’s no wonder we voted in our millions to leave.We must now go to Brussels with an offer that guarantees control of our borders and sign our own trade deals.But we mustn’t for a second think that they’ll just say yes to it, nor can the PM let them fatally weaken it.It is galling that ministers have spent more time fighting between themselves than preparing for a “no deal” exit.But it isn’t too late.New technology can ensure that Whitehall and our borders are ready for a clean break, which considering the strength of our economy and our companies is nothing to be scared of.The PM has dumped many of her earlier Brexit slogans. But she should remember one in particular now.No deal really is better than a bad deal, and we must still prepare for it.

title: theresa may housing policy election
story: There are all kinds of answers.A social care policy that went down among elderly Tory voters like a cup of cold novichok.A leader who repeated the phrase “strong and stable” so much the record started to scratch.But the statistics tell a simpler story — they lost it because of HOUSING.The voters who drove Labour’s turnout surge were those who used to be able to own homes, but now can’t.This “rentquake”, according to pollster Matt Singh, was enough to explain 77 per cent of the swing to Labour.These young voters are furious. And they’re right to be.As recently as 1991, a third of those aged 16 to 24 owned their own home.Now, that figure is ten per cent.For those aged 25 to 34, the rate has fallen from 66 per cent to 38 per cent.Home ownership rates in Britain are now the fourth lowest in the EU, and we have the second highest proportion of social housing, i.e., people living in homes provided by the State.Earlier this year, we at the Centre for Policy Studies commissioned polling asking young people how government could make their lives better.The top answer was clear — they want housing to be more affordable.And not via cheaper rents — by a three-to-one margin, they wanted the Government to prioritise home ownership.Strikingly, only three per cent of those aged 18 to 24 told us they never wanted to own their own home.They just can’t see themselves being able to afford it for years — often decades.This is a crisis with many causes.The persistent failure, stretching back decades, to build enough new homes. A dysal planning system.Existing homeowners who don’t want their communities disrupted or their views spoiled.A Labour government that made it much easier for buy-to-let landlords to snap up those homes that were being built, and much harder for first-time buyers to do the same — and a financial crash which made that problem so much worse. Yet it’s also a crisis with many solutions.Making it easier to extend or expand existing properties. Changing Green Belt regulations so we protect our most beautul countryside while building on pig farms, or beside railway stations or motorways or electricity substations or other decidedly non-green and unpleasant bits of land.Finding ways  to turn renters into owners, as Margaret Thatcher did with the Right to Buy for council tenants in the 1980s, with more than a little success.But the sad truth is that while the Government has succeeded in dragging up construction levels, it is still not thinking anywhere near radically enough.“Since my very first day in Downing Street, I have made it my personal mission to fix our broken housing system,” Theresa May told the National Housing Federation yesterday.But that mission is in grave jeopardy.A year ago, the Prime Minister endured a triple whammy of embarrassment in her party conference speech — being handed a P45 by a prankster, developing a crippling cough, then seeing the slogan behind her start to fall off.Mrs May bravely endured these trials. But she could do little about the fact that her promise in the same speech to “make the British dream a reality by igniting home ownership once again” was built around a £10billion expansion of the Help to Buy scheme.A scheme which pretty much every economist, including the Government’s own Office for Budget Responsibility, says is mostly serving to push up house prices and make colossally rich housebuilders even richer.Indeed, even as Mrs May was speaking, their collective share price spiked by £1BILLION.Yesterday, the Prime Minister ed to the subject.In a speech to the National Housing Summit, she promised another £2billion for social housing.But even on its own terms, Mrs May’s proposal isn’t a blunderbuss.It’s a pinprick. Not only is the £2billion spread over a decade but it’s a small fraction of the amount that George Osborne cut from the same budgets.And it fits a wider pattern. For all the Government’s rhetoric, the big ideas to get Britain building just aren’t there.One of the keys to David Cameron’s election victory in 2015 — right there on the first page of the Tory manesto — was a promise to extend the Right to Buy to housing associations and to build 200,000 starter homes.The commitment was to create two million more homeowners within five years.As of May 2018, not a single one of those starter homes had been built — and the expansion of Right to Buy is still lodged in the gullet of the Whitehall machine.It’s the same pattern on planning reform.Sajid Javid’s robust proposals as Communities Secretary to break up the oligopoly of the big housebuilders, free up more land and speed up development — all badly needed — were neutered by Downing Street, because it was paranoid about upsetting traditional Tory voters who don’t like the sight of bulldozers.When the Government’s new planning framework was announced in March, the headlines were about building more and higher-quality homes.But the small print made it so that councils could get away with building fewer houses, not more.I don’t doubt that Mrs May’s heart is in the right place.But  she and her team don’t pluck up their courage on housing — and take far more dramatic steps both to build more houses and create more homeowners — they’ll almost certainly lose the next election. More than that, they’ll deserve to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: rod liddle immigration post brexit
story: Immigration. A vexed issue. Complain about it and people will call you a racist.That’s a popular way of shutting down debate these days. Just screech “raaacisst” at someone.I’d go so far as to say it’s one of the reasons Leave won the referendum — because ordinary people were sick of being called racist when they simply worried about the millions of people who have arrived here in the past ten years.About seven million, in fact. An astonishing number.The Prime Minister is about to draw up her plans for immigration post-Brexit.She will be taking advice from the Migration Advisory Committee . It has suggested we allow in skilled workers who might be vital to our economy.It has also suggested we clamp down on low-skilled migrants.This seems to me a perfectly sensible argument. We should not entirely close ourselves off from the world. And there are foreign nationals here who do excellent work for our country. And pay good taxes.At the same time, the vast influx of low-skilled workers has had a terrible effect upon our country.Some towns — such as Boston in Lincolnshire — have been effectively taken over.And as the MAC found, the vast reservoir of labour has depressed the wages of British people at the lowest end of the scale. It has hurt the poorest of us.But it doesn’t only hurt us. You’ll have seen the squalid conditions in which a lot of these low-paid foreign workers live. This is exploitation, on a massive scale.How any leftie can support it absolutely befoggles me.Living below the minimum wage, crammed into rotten accommodation — all so companies such as Amazon can make a bigger profit.No wonder the big companies were the first to complain. Listen: Pay your workers a decent, living wage in future and shut up, huh?But this is an overcrowded country. It is ludicrous to suggest that the millions we have allowed in have not had a massive effect on our infrastructure.It’s why we need to pave over more and more of the countryside to build homes, for example. The MAC suggested house prices had risen as a consequence — and our homes already cost too much.There’s pressure on our schools, our hospitals and our transport networks.Well, with any luck this will all come to an end. Perhaps the Government might also abide by its pledge to get yearly immigration levels down to the tens of thousands, rather than the hundreds of thousands as it is at the moment.But at the same time we should look after the EU migrants we have already let in, and ensure they feel secure and safe living in Britain.Do all that and I’ll be a happy man. Even  the lefties still shriek “raaacisst” every few seconds.GIRLS – looking for something to wear for a night out? You’ll find it in a drawer in your kitchen.They come in rolls for about £1.50 from Asda. Yep, it’s the black bin liner, as sported here by Megan Barton Hanson.I have no idea, incidentally, who Megan Barton Hanson is, still less her boyfriend called “Wes”.BBC Radio 6 presenter Cerys Matthews says she refuses to play music made by people who went to private school.OK, Cerys. That means your entire back catalogue is banned, seeing as you were educated at the expensive St Michael’s School in Llanelli.A few weeks ago a BBC executive said he wouldn’t be commissioning comedies from public schoolboys .Spouting every right-on opinion that suddenly swings into fashion?Here’s a tip, Cerys. Play the best rock, folk and soul music you can find.The stuff that sounds the most interesting.You’ll find that auto- matically the private school musicians will be excluded anyway – including yourself.APPARENTLY President Trump’s penis closely resembles a toadstool.This is according to Stormy Daniels, who says she had an affair with Donald.The question is, though – what kind of toadstool?There are hundreds of thousands of species. Was it a fly agaric? That’s the one with a big red head covered in white spots. If so, Donald ought to get himself to a doctor.Or maybe it’s that one with a thin stalk and a big yellow head the size of a dinner plate.If so, Stormy had better get herself to a doctor.A “RELATIONSHIP expert” has warned us all about dodgy body language  we’re out on a date.Tracey Cox says we shouldn’t fidget, for a start. What, even  we’ve taken her to a ballet?Also, don’t wring your hands or sit in a slumped manner, and so on.Hmm. As a “relationship expert” I offer the following advice to blokes out on a first date in a restaurant.2. Don’t pass wind then waft the air saying “Mmmmm, Bisto!”3. When they bring the black pepper, don’t sneeze on her pasta.4. If you do sneeze on her pasta, stir it around a bit when she’s not looking.5. Don’t use a bread stick to excavate the contents of your ear.6. Don’t keep checking the football scores on your phone. And shouting loudly: “Lee Gregory! 85th minute! Get IN you f***er!”7. Don’t ask the lady at the next table  she’s up for a threesome.Follow that stuff and you can fidget away to your heart’s delight. You’ll be OK.THERE’S a crisis in our wildle. Some of our favourite species of birds or mammals are on the brink of extinction.The corn bunting, for example, and the hedgehog.As TV wildle campaigner Chris Packham rightly says, this is because we have paved over the countryside to build ever more homes.And because of the intensive farming methods – which have seen the eradication of farmland birds.Packham has drawn up a “People’s Manesto for Wildle” which includes stuff like twinning city schools with farms, so that kids grow up with an understanding of nature.There’s also a demo at Hyde Park in London on Saturday. I’ll be there. Don’t forget – as Joni Mitchell once sang, you don’t know what you’ve got ’til its gone.SO, it looks very much as  the old Irish border problem is going to be solved very quickly after all.We’re close to agreeing a deal with the European Union which will enable Northern Ireland to retain its “soft border”.The Remainers said it couldn’t be done. Totally impossible. But  we don’t want a hard border and the Irish don’t want a hard border – who is going to make us have one?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says housing revolution
story: The latest cash injection is derisory.The Government is trumpeting £2billion of new funding for housing associations over six years from 2022. That’s just 7,000 homes a year nationwide.Our population is increasing by almost 400,000 a year. The annual ­target for new homes is 300,000 — and we doubt even that would lower prices enough for young people to afford to buy in London and the South East.In fairness, the total HAS risen to 217,000 a year, the most since 2007. But it’s still way short — and the Government’s remedies are woefully timid.Sajid Javid promised a huge shake-up when he ran housing. He was knocked back by the negativity from Philip Hammond’s Treasury. Then he moved on.We need to slash planning restrictions and defy obstructive NIMBYs. We need to stop the land-banking that sees developers hoard plots or release homes at a snail’s pace to keep prices high.We need more cash help for small builders. We should borrow billions, build affordable homes on public land and sell them at a profit for the Treasury.The Tories need to wake up or housing will sink them. Instead they are hyping up some footling new funding that only partly reverses a previous cut.It fools no one.WHY is the EU wasting time pressing for a border between Britain and Northern ­Ireland? It’s a non-starter.No Government could consider it. Especially not one entirely reliant on the votes of those most vehemently opposed to splitting up the UK, the DUP.This cannot be news to Brussels. They cannot believe Theresa May will surrender and collapse her Government.Why persist with it? The answer must be: to run down the clock — until, at the last minute, Mrs May agrees virtually anything to avoid a No Deal.Which is why Donald Tusk also still insists key areas of our wildly over-generous Chequers offer must be “reworked”.Mrs May has gone as far as she can. Two Cabinet figures have quit already. She must insist it’s take it or leave it.Only Britain has made genuine compromises in this negotiation, as despondent Brexiteers know only too well.It’s the EU’s turn.FROM child abuse images to terrorism, Facebook is a platform for evil it seems unable or unwilling to prevent.Now it is hosting ads for people- smuggling gangs luring children to their doom in the Mediterranean.A new low, even for a tech giant with apparently no moral compass.Since Facebook now admits it is a publisher, why isn’t it regulated as one?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says eu brexit mobsters
story: EU leaders promised a fair hearing on our future relationship at yesterday’s crunch Salzburg summit.Instead, Mrs May was ambushed with a cack-handed attempt to sign us up to Brussels’ unacceptable terms there and then.The PM refused to budge on the UK’s red lines, and she’s absolutely right to do so. This lot are more Bugsy Malone than Al Capone.Yesterday the leaders of the undemocratic European Union showed their true colours.This isn’t some grand project, designed to bring the peoples of Europe together in one happy union. It’s a protection racket.But even before the Prime Minister had been the subject of calculated attempts to humiliate her, we saw just how detached from reality Europe’s leaders have become.Maltese and Czech leaders told Britain to hold a second referendum, employing the same tactic that the EU has used in Ireland and Denmark before.This isn’t based on the half-baked “democratic” argument clung to by never-were and past-it grandees at home, such as Andrew Adonis and Lord Heseltine.They just want us to be given the chance to vote the “right” way. Fat chance of that. Throughout this process, the European Union has shown time and time again why more than 17 million people voted to leave.They have refused to negotiate in good faith. They have refused to compromise, even while Britain has worked day-in, day-out to find agreement.They have insulted the Prime Minister, ignored their own citizens, and are willing to accept a massive economic hit for the sake of flexing their muscles.Like all good gangsters, they’re trying to rule by fear. That’s the only weapon in their arsenal on the Continent, where more and more voters are turning against an outfit that increasingly looks more at home in Sicily than Strasbourg.All they have is the chance to punish us, and prove to the rest of the continent that it isn’t worth leaving.The message they want to send? You won’t get away with it.Well, Mrs May is right to say that we’ve nothing to be scared of.Yes, it is without doubt that we need to pick up the pace on preparations for a clean-break Brexit.It is vital we show the European Union, who still seem to think we’ll roll over when it really matters, that we are ready for a new future free of their cold, dead hands.And despite no-marks such as Donald Tusk trolling the PM on Instagram, and the puffed-up pomposity of France’s Emmanuel Macron and Ireland’s Leo Varadkar, we haven’t entirely given up hope that sensible forces within the EU might find their voice in the crucial months to come — and work with the UK, not against it.The Government should be all ears  Brussels makes us an offer that works for both sides.But after yesterday’s performance, we don’t hold out much hope.Brussels has made us an offer it thinks we can’t refuse.Today we join the Prime Minister in saying no.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: fat controller chris the rank engine
story: He decides what engines take the trains out and what carriages they have to haul. He sets the timetable and makes decisions over which engines should be scrapped. The problem with today’s railway ­system is that there is nobody who takes on the role.That was made clear in the report by Professor Stephen Glaister, the chairman of the Office Of Rail And Road, into the chaos that paralysed the railways in May following an extensive timetable change.In a logical world, you might think, dear rail passenger, that Chris Grayling, the Secretary Of State For Transport, is the man in charge. After all, he is the one who pops up on TV when there is good news to announce, such as the opening of a refurbished ­station or the introduction of new trains, but you would be wrong.Grayling refuses to take responsibility, recently telling a Parliamentary committee that “I don’t run the railways”. Yet his civil servants in the Department interfere with the railways all the time. They make decisions over what ­services should be run, the fares to be charged, what new trains should be bought and which private company should operate them.Prof Glaister’s report makes clear that Grayling was deeply involved in making the decision to go ahead with the timetable changes, even though the ­industry was not prepared for them. If Grayling was not in charge, then he should have made sure that someone else was — but failed to do so.It’s clear from the report no one has overall responsibility for the ­railways, and that’s why they are in such a mess.Prof Glaister’s report highlights the fact that the railways were simply not ready to cope with the wholesale ­timetable changes, which were focused around ­services through London on the Thameslink lines and across the North, and ­overall affected nearly half — 46 per cent — of trains on the whole network.The report shows that the railway ­simply could not cope. The changes brought the service to its knees, resulting in thousands of services being ­cancelled and countless others delayed. Many passengers in May were left standing at stations for hours as ­successive trains failed to turn up.On one branch line in the Lake District, services were cancelled entirely and temporarily replaced by a diesel-hauled heritage train — which proved to be more popular than the usual service, especially as it was free.The introduction of the timetable resulted in the worst performance of the railways in more than a decade, with one in eight trains running late during this period. The after-effects are still being felt today, with daily cancellations and delays, and it will be several months before things are back to normal.Prof Glaister does not mince his words and found every part of the industry wanting. Network Rail, which is responsible for drawing up the timetable, “did not take any action” back in the autumn when it was clear there would be trouble ­implementing the new schedules.Two train operators, Govia Thameslink and Northern, “were not sufficiently aware” of the problems and failed to inform passengers when disruption ­occurred, while the Department For Transport and the Office Of Rail And Road itself watched these events unfold without doing anything or questioning whether the introduction of the timetable should be postponed.The irony is that the timetable changes were introduced to increase the number of trains available to commuters. In ­particular, in the North, the opening of the new Ordsall Chord linking ­Manchester’s two main railway stations was designed to improve services in the region.However, because Network Rail failed to ensure that more platforms were built at the biggest station, Piccadilly, rather than improvements for local passengers the result has been longer delays and ­numerous cancellations.That is precisely the sort of lack of co-ordination which happens because ­British Rail was broken up on its privatisation in the 1990s into more than 100 companies. Passengers are paying the price for that mistake today.The biggest error was to separate the services, run by companies including ­Virgin and Arriva, from the infrastructure, which is in the hands of Network Rail , when, in fact, the railways run much better as a single entity.Ironically, the Prime Minister at the time, John Major, had wanted the railway to be sold off as just four or five large companies that ran services and were responsible for the tracks and stations, but he was overruled by the Treasury, which wanted competition between ­companies — something that has simply not happened.As a result of the timetable chaos and other recent problems on the railways, such as the failure of the East Coast franchise and overspending on ­electrication schemes by Network Rail, Grayling has launched an inquiry into the state of the railways. It is the fourth such inquiry in the past decade and the others have largely been ignored.This time there is an obvious and clear solution. Create an organisation ­independent of the duffers in Whitehall who keep on interfering with the railways, and make sure it is headed by a Fat ­Controller who has power to make ­decisions over the whole railway, ­including the timetable, investment plans and ­services.Inevitably, this will at first have to be a publicly-owned body, since Network Rail is currently owned by the Government.But to appease any Tories opposed to renationalisation, Grayling could say that eventually it might be privatised — though given the experience of the crisis-ridden past 20 years, that day may well be a long time off.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
